title: The Sever's Disease Protocol
author: james-scott
description: The definitive isometric routine to kill heel pain in growing athletes. Stop icing and start strengthening the soleus muscle where it matters most.
coachNote: James's Take: Rest doesn't fix Sever's; it just hides it. The pain comes from the calf pulling on the heel bone's growth plate. We use 'Iso-Holds' to create an analgesic (pain-killing) effect without impact. This is the same protocol I use with D1 athletes.

steps.title: The Floating Heel
steps.instruction: Stand on a stair or weight plate with just the balls of your feet. Lower your heels 1 inch below the step level. HOLD this position without moving. You should feel tension in your lower calf.

steps.title: Soleus Squat Hold
steps.instruction: Stand with knees bent at 30 degrees. Rise onto the balls of your feet and HOLD. This bent-knee position targets the soleus—the specific muscle pulling on the growth plate.

steps.title: Wall Lean Iso
steps.instruction: Face a wall, lean forward with straight body, heels just off the ground. Hold this angled position. Your calves should burn but your heels should NOT hurt above 3/10 pain.

steps.title: Single-Leg Balance (Heel Hover)
steps.instruction: Stand on one foot, heel slightly elevated off the ground. Hold for 30 seconds each side. This builds foot stability while loading the calf isometrically.

coachingCues: Pain during holds should NOT exceed 3/10—if it does, reduce the hold time
Do NOT stretch aggressively—this can irritate the growth plate more
Perform this protocol BEFORE activity to 'pre-load' the tendon
Consistency beats intensity—do this daily, not just when it hurts
commonMistake: Aggressive calf stretching thinking it will help
mistakeFix: Stop stretching during flare-ups. Use isometrics only. Stretching can actually pull harder on the irritated growth plate.
